citeinfo.title: Appalachian National Scenic Trail Centerline

pubinfo.publish: National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office & Appalachian Trail Conservancy

citeinfo.origin: National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office & Appalachian Trail Conservancy

descript.abstract:
This data set represents the most current depiction of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail centerline.
Locational information used to create this data set were obtained from Global Positioning Systems (GPS) survey data collected between 1999-2013 using mostly Trimble GPS equipment.
descript.purpose: This data set was developed to provide a depiction of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail in an usable and easily transferable format between parties so that it can correctly be represented on digital and printed maps; to assist staff members, agency partners, and trail-maintaining clubs with trail and land management duties; and to help local planning agencies, telecommunications companies, and other groups with planning activities, such as siting new developments that could have a substantial impact on the scenic quality of the Appalachian Trail.
descript.supplinf:
The Appalachian National Scenic Trail is a footpath over 2,170 miles in length that traverses the Appalachian Mountains from Maine to Georgia. It passes through 14 states and approximately 241 jurisdictions, and links some 75 national and state parks and forests. Virtually every mile is within easy access of a major population center and some portion of the trail is within a day's drive of 2/3rds of the U.S. population.
The idea for an Appalachian Trail was conceived by forester Benton MacKaye in 1921. In 1925, he formed the Appalachian Trail Conference (now called the Appalachian Trail Conservancy), a private not-for-profit organization whose mission is to protect, preserve, manage, and promote the Appalachian Trail. By 1937, an Appalachian Trail footpath was considered complete and open for all to enjoy. In 1968, Congress passed the National Scenic Trails Act that created a system of national scenic trails, starting with the Appalachian Trail and Pacific Crest Trail.
Today, the trail and its associated lands are managed by the National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office and Appalachian Trail Conservancy, in conjunction with 31 affiliated trail clubs and several other partners including the USDA Forest Service and numerous state park and state forest agencies.

idinfo.accconst: It is asked that proper citation (credit: National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office and Appalachian Trail Conservancy, 2014) be used on any materials (digital or printed) in which this information appears.
idinfo.useconst: Although a large portion of this data is quite accurate, the information depicted in this data set is for general reference purposes only and does not represent legal survey information. The National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, other partners (including other units of the National Park Service and the USDA Forest Service), and associated trail-maintaining clubs shall not be held responsible for use or misuse of this data. Please see the Distribution_Liability section for more detailed information.

cntperp.cntorg: National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office

idinfo.datacred: National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office and Appalachian Trail Conservancy
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcGIS 10.0.5.4400

attracc.attraccr: All attributes associated with this data set were verified and should reflect the qualities of each portion of the data. Length (distance) information was calculated within the GIS though, so may not accurately reflect true distance values such as those calculated on the ground with a wheel or other measuring device. These values may also vary slightly throughout the data set, depending on the source data used to determine length.

dataqual.logic: Information within this data set are considered to be logically consistent, though no formal tests were performed.
dataqual.complete: The Appalachian National Scenic Trail centerline data was created from high accuracy Global Positioning System (GPS) data collected by Dr. Vernon Vernier (1999-2003), Karl Hartzell and John Fletcher (2005), and Appalachian Trail Conservancy and National Park Service staff (2001-2013), using mainly Trimble GPS equipment, with some supplemental data from trail partners. All data are post-processed differently corrected where possible. As more accurate and up-to-date information is collected or becomes available, it will be incorporated within, or used to update, the current data set.

horizpa.horizpar: Data in this data set are based on centerline data collected mainly with Trimble GPS equipment and post-process differentially corrected. While horizontal accuracy may vary slightly, the data is generally less than 5 meters accurate. All portions of the data meet National Mapping Standards of +/- 46.5 feet horizontal accuracy at a 95% confidence level.

procstep.procdesc:
The Appalachian National Scenic Trail Centerline data was created from high accuracy Global Positioning System (GPS) data collected by Dr. Vernon Vernier (1999-2003), Karl Hartzell and John Fletcher (2005), and Appalachian Trail Conservancy and National Park Service staff (2001-2013), using mainly Trimble GPS equipment, with some supplemental data collected by trail partners. All data are post-processed differently corrected where possible.
As more accurate and up-to-date information is collected or becomes available, it will be incorporated within, or used to update, the current data set.

srcinfo.srccontr: Information used in compiling this data set was collected and contributed by Dr. Vernon Vernier (1999-2003), Karl Hartzell and John Fletcher (2005), and Appalachian Trail Conservancy and National Park Service staff (2001-2013), with some supplemental data from trail partners.

citeinfo.title: Appalachian National Scenic Trail Centerline
citeinfo.origin: National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office and Appalachian Trail Conservancy

pubinfo.publish: National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office and Appalachian Trail Conservancy

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

distinfo.resdesc: This data set was developed to support the A.T. project and the mission and goals of the National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office and Appalachian Trail Conservancy.
distinfo.distliab:
Although a large portion of this data is quite accurate, the information depicted in this data set is for general reference purposes only and does not represent legal survey information. The National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, other partners (including other units of the National Park Service and the USDA Forest Service), and associated trail-maintaining clubs shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such.
The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent with the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. The related graphics are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not appropriate to use the related graphics as data.
The National Park Service and Appalachian Trail Conservancy give no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data be directly acquired from NPS or ATC and not indirectly through other sources that may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at both the National Park Service and Appalachian Trail Conservancy, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

lineage.Process: Buffer at_latest D:\ATGIS\Data\Trail\Buffer\at_latest_5_mile_buffer2.shp "500 Feet" FULL ROUND ALL #
CalculateField at_latest COMMENTS "Adjusted location based on 2013 Trail Assessment" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline SOURCE "Based on 2005 GPS Survey with ProXRS, adjusted slightly w/aerial imagery" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline SOURCE "Based on 2005 GPS Survey with ProXRS, adjusted based on 2013 assessment data" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline SOURCE "Based on 2005 GPS Survey with ProXRS, adjusted based on 2012 trail assessment" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline SOURCE "Based on 2005 GPS Survey with ProXRS, adjusted based on 2012 trail assessment" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline SOURCE "Based on 2005 GPS Survey with ProXRS, with adjustments based on 2013 & 2012 data" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline STATUS "Official A.T. Route" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline SOURCE "Based on 2005 GPS Survey with ProXRS, adjusted based on 2013 assessment data" VB #
CalculateField at_centerline COMMENTS "Adjusted location based on 2013 Trail Assessment" VB #

Locational information used to create this data set were obtained from Global Positioning Systems (GPS) survey data collected between 1999-2014 using mostly Trimble GPS equipment.
dataIdInfo.idPurp: This data set was developed to provide a depiction of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail in an usable and easily transferable format between parties so that it can correctly be represented on digital and printed maps; to assist staff members, agency partners, and trail-maintaining clubs with trail and land management duties; and to help local planning agencies, telecommunications companies, and other groups with planning activities, such as siting new developments that could have a substantial impact on the scenic quality of the Appalachian Trail.

dataIdInfo.suppInfo: The Appalachian National Scenic Trail is a footpath over 2,170 miles in length that traverses the Appalachian Mountains from Maine to Georgia. It passes through 14 states and approximately 241 jurisdictions, and links some 75 national and state parks and forests. Virtually every mile is within easy access of a major population center and some portion of the trail is within a day's drive of 2/3rds of the U.S. population. The idea for an Appalachian Trail was conceived by forester Benton MacKaye in 1921. In 1925, he formed the Appalachian Trail Conference (now called the Appalachian Trail Conservancy), a private not-for-profit organization whose mission is to protect, preserve, manage, and promote the Appalachian Trail. By 1937, an Appalachian Trail footpath was considered complete and open for all to enjoy. In 1968, Congress passed the National Scenic Trails Act that created a system of national scenic trails, starting with the Appalachian Trail and Pacific Crest Trail. Today, the trail and its associated lands are managed by the National Park Service Appalachian Trail Park Office and Appalachian Trail Conservancy, in conjunction with several partners including 31 affiliated trail clubs, the USDA Forest Service and numerous state park and state forest agencies.
dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.2.3552

report.evalMethDesc: Information within this data set are considered to be logically consistent, though no formal tests were performed. Line geometry is topologically clean.

report.measDesc: Information within this data set are considered to be logically consistent, though no formal tests were performed. Line geometry is topologically clean.

The Appalachian National Scenic Trail centerline data was created from high accuracy Global Positioning System (GPS) data collected by Dr. Vernon Vernier (1999-2003), Karl Hartzell and John Fletcher (2005), and Appalachian Trail Conservancy and National Park Service staff (2001-2013), using mainly Trimble GPS equipment, with some supplemental data from trail partners. All data are post-processed differently corrected where possible. As more accurate and up-to-date information is collected or becomes available, it will be incorporated within, or used to update, the current data set.

All attributes associated with this data set were verified and should reflect the qualities of each portion of the data. Length (distance) information was calculated within the GIS though, so may not accurately reflect true distance values such as those calculated on the ground with a wheel or other measuring device. These values may also vary slightly throughout the data set, depending on the source data used to determine length.

All data in this data set were collected with Trimble GPS equipment and post-process differentially corrected. While horizontal accuracy may vary slightly, the data is generally less than 5 meters accurate. All portions of the data meet National Mapping Standards of +/- 46.5 feet horizontal accuracy at a 95% confidence level.

prcStep.stepDesc: The Appalachian National Scenic Trail Centerline data was created from high accuracy Global Positioning System (GPS) data collected by Dr. Vernon Vernier (1999-2003), Karl Hartzell and John Fletcher (2005), and Appalachian Trail Conservancy and National Park Service staff (2001-2013), using mainly Trimble GPS equipment, with some supplemental data collected by trail partners. All data are post-processed differently corrected where possible. As more accurate and up-to-date information is collected or becomes available, it will be incorporated within, or used to update, the current data set.

dataSource.srcDesc: Information used in compiling this data set was collected and contributed by Dr. Vernon Vernier (1999-2003), Karl Hartzell and John Fletcher (2005), and Appalachian Trail Conservancy and National Park Service staff (2001-2013), with some supplemental data from trail partners.
